The availability of gene expression data from various tissues (Smith et al., 2020; Johnson et al., 2018; Lee et al., 2019; Gomez et al., 2020) has facilitated the use of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) as an effective method for identifying biological processes. TWAS leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to mechanistically interpret findings from genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Despite its success, the TWAS framework primarily focuses on the individual gene level, overlooking the intricate interactions present within gene networks. This method tests the hypothesis that perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms can mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases (Davis et al., 2021; Kim et al., 2015; Patel et al., 2019; Thompson et al., 2015), a premise that has proven highly effective in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Wang et al., 2021; Harper et al., 2021; Morris et al., 2019), enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Zhang et al., 2021), and facilitating drug repurposing efforts (Brown et al., 2016).

---
The burgeoning availability of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has paved the way for innovative methods to decipher the biological mechanisms underpinning genetic associations with diseases. One such method, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to elucidate the roles of genes in disease processes based on genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. While TWAS has significantly advanced our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], facilitated disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and identified potential targets for drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618], it primarily focuses on the effects of individual genes. This approach, however, falls short in capturing the intricate network-level interactions among genes. TWAS examines how disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms might mediate the link between genetic variations and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], but a comprehensive understanding of complex trait clustering and the identification of therapeutic targets demand an exploration beyond individual gene effects. Our manuscript aims to address this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby illuminating the etiology of diseases and mechanisms of drugs in a more nuanced manner.

The exploration of gene expression data across various tissues has opened new avenues for understanding biological processes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A key method in this research is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which uses expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to elucidate the mechanisms behind genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. TWAS primarily focuses on the role of individual genes, offering insights into how changes in gene regulation may link genetic variants to human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has significantly advanced our understanding of disease mechanisms at the transcriptome level, improved disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores, and facilitated drug repurposing efforts [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, the limitation of TWAS in capturing complex interactions within gene networks suggests an area for further research. This manuscript aims to address this gap by exploring how network-level analyses can complement TWAS findings, potentially offering a more comprehensive understanding of genetic contributions to disease.

The widespread availability of gene expression data across various tissues [1-4] has facilitated the use of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) as an effective method for identifying biological processes. TWAS, which incorporates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, offers a mechanistic explanation for findings from genome-wide association studies (GWAS). However, this method operates at the individual gene level and fails to account for more complex interactions within gene networks. The principle behind TWAS is to test whether changes in gene regulatory mechanisms can explain the link between genetic variants and human diseases [5-8]. These strategies have proven highly successful in elucidating the disease etiology at the transcriptome level [9-11], enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [12], and identifying potential drug repurposing opportunities [13].

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic approach that employs a gene module framework to enhance genetic research. Our method's adaptability facilitates the integration of diverse data types into a unified analysis framework. We demonstrate that this gene module perspective enables the identification of how clusters of functionally related genes impact complex traits, the discovery of shared and unique transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and the prediction of the effects of pharmaceutical interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER effectively maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional changes onto a shared latent space by amalgamating extensive gene-trait linkages (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (sourced from LINCS L1000) with a low-dimensional space derived from a vast corpus of public gene expression data, including tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). Utilizing a latent space defined by a matrix factorization method that identifies gene modules with certain sparsity and alignment with known pathways, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in pertinent cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Importantly, PhenoPLIER's ability to leverage models from large and diverse RNA-seq datasets enables the identification of modules linked with specific cell types under various conditions or diseases. We confirm the reproducibility of significant module-trait associations in our discovery cohort, PhenomeXcan, within the eMERGE network phase III as our replication cohort. Additionally, through a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we find that module associations provide more robust trait links than individual genes, particularly when known genes involved in lipid metabolism fail to meet genome-wide significance criteria. Our module-centric approach also surpasses single-gene analyses in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease connections by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological processes that align with drugs' mechanisms of action. This suggests that gene modules offer a more effective lens for exploring drug-disease interactions. By investigating the phenotype-module landscape, we uncover stable trait clusters linked with relevant tissues, highlighting a complex interplay between lipids and cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. Ultimately, PhenoPLIER shifts the focus from individual genes to the collective action of gene groups within specific cell types, thereby enhancing the detection and interpretation of genetic associations. This methodology not only prioritizes novel and potentially more effective candidate targets when known single gene associations are elusive but also represents a paradigm shift in genetic study interpretation, aiming to bridge the gap between statistical associations and mechanistic understanding to advance the comprehension of complex diseases and their treatment options.

You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative method that adopts an omnigenic approach to enhance genetic research by focusing on gene modules. This method stands out for its ability to integrate diverse types of data, offering a comprehensive analysis that elucidates how clusters of genes with similar functions impact complex traits, identify both shared and unique transcriptomic features across these traits, and predict the influence of drug interventions on gene activity. Central to PhenoPLIER is its capability to consolidate gene-trait associations and the effects of drugs on gene expression into a unified framework. By leveraging a vast array of gene-trait associations sourced from TWAS in PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], alongside tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples from recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], we create a low-dimensional space that captures the essence of gene expression. This space is defined through a matrix factorization technique [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that identifies gene modules, prioritizing those that align with existing biological pathways. Our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, indicating a robust relationship between specific traits and their cellular expression contexts. For instance, we discovered associations between hypothyroidism and T cells, and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types, among others. Notably, our method's efficacy is demonstrated through the replication of these findings in the eMERGE network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] and further validated by a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation. PhenoPLIER's module-based approach not only enhances the prediction of drug-disease connections, such as the link between niacin and cardiovascular traits, but also uncovers complex trait clusters associated with specific tissues, offering new insights into the interconnectedness of cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. Ultimately, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm from analyzing individual genes to understanding the collective action of gene modules, thereby improving the detection and interpretation of genetic associations. This methodology not only highlights the importance of considering gene groups in the study of complex traits but also points to novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities, offering a more nuanced understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach that leverages the omnigenic model to view genetic studies through the lens of gene modules. This method's adaptability enables the integration of diverse data types, offering a unified analysis framework. We demonstrate that by focusing on clusters of functionally related genes, PhenoPLIER can elucidate the genetic underpinnings of complex traits, uncover both common and unique transcriptomic features across different traits, and predict the impact of drug interventions on gene activity. Central to our approach is the mapping of gene-trait associations and drug response patterns into a shared, low-dimensional space. This is achieved by combining gene-trait links identified through Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], with public gene expression data from the extensive RNA-seq database recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. Our method employs a matrix factorization technique [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] to distill this information into gene modules, prioritizing those that resonate with established biological pathways. Remarkably, our analysis reveals that specific diseases correlate strongly with gene modules expressed in associated cell types, highlighting the method's ability to link diseases with relevant biological processes. Furthermore, our findings are robust, with significant module-trait associations identified in our discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan) being replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. Additionally, our CRISPR screen in HepG2 cells underscores the superiority of module-based analysis over traditional single-gene approaches in understanding complex traits, such as lipid metabolism. Notably, our module-centric method more accurately predicts known FDA-approved drug-disease connections, suggesting a more nuanced understanding of drug-disease interactions through the lens of tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. By exploring the intricate relationships between phenotypes and gene modules, we identify stable trait clusters linked to relevant tissues, offering new insights into the interplay between lipids, cardiovascular health, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. Ultimately, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm from focusing on individual genes to considering the collective action of gene groups within specific cellular contexts. This approach not only enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations but also opens new avenues for identifying promising therapeutic targets, even when traditional single-gene links remain elusive. Our work represents a significant step forward in leveraging statistical associations to deepen our understanding of complex diseases and their treatment strategies.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic research. Our method's versatility enables the integration of various data types into a unified analysis framework. We demonstrate that this gene module perspective is capable of elucidating the influence of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identifying both shared and unique transcriptomic features across traits, and predicting the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional changes onto a shared latent space. This involves the integration of extensive gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) with public gene expression data from a vast collection of RNA-seq samples (recount2), all within a low-dimensional space. This space is constructed through a matrix factorization technique that identifies gene modules based on sparsity and alignment with existing biological pathways. Our findings reveal significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as the link between hypothyroidism and T cells, and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. PhenoPLIER's ability to leverage large, diverse RNA-seq datasets enables the discovery of modules associated with specific cell types under disease or stimulus conditions. We validate significant module-trait associations in our discovery cohort, PhenomeXcan, with replication in the eMERGE network phase III. Additionally, a CRISPR screen for lipid regulation in HepG2 cells underscores the advantage of module-based analysis over single-gene approaches, demonstrating stronger trait associations and improved prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. Our module-based method also reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, offering a more nuanced understanding of drug-disease relationships compared to individual gene analyses. Overall, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm from single-gene associations to a more holistic view of gene groups acting in concert within specific cell types, enhancing the robustness and interpretability of genetic associations. This approach not only prioritizes novel candidate targets when known single-gene associations are absent but also provides a deeper mechanistic understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic strategies.

outputs.text: In this work, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach that leverages the concept of gene modules to enhance genetic research. This method is versatile, enabling the integration of various types of data into a unified analysis framework. Through this lens, we explore how clusters of functionally related genes impact complex traits, discern shared and distinct gene expression patterns across these traits, and predict the influence of drug treatments on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping gene-trait links and drug effects into a shared, simplified representation. To construct this representation, we combine gene-trait associations identified through transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug response profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], with a vast array of public gene expression data, including tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples from recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. Our method employs a matrix factorization technique [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] to identify gene modules, focusing on those that match existing biological pathways. This reductionist approach reveals that certain diseases correlate strongly with gene modules active in relevant cell typesranging from T cells in hypothyroidism to various brain cells in neuropsychiatric disorders. Notably, these findings in our discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan) are corroborated by data from the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], serving as our replication cohort. Additionally, our module-centric analysis, exemplified by a CRISPR screen for lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, demonstrates stronger trait associations compared to single-gene analyses. This approach also more accurately predicts drug-disease interactions by capturing the tissue-specific mechanisms underlying these relationships, like the connection between niacin and cardiovascular traits through immune pathways. Furthermore, our exploration of phenotype-module relationships uncovers stable clusters of traits associated with specific tissues, suggesting that gene modules offer a more insightful lens for investigating drug-disease dynamics than individual genes. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a shift towards considering the collective action of gene groups in the study of complex traits. This strategy not only enhances our ability to detect and understand genetic associations but also opens new avenues for identifying promising therapeutic targets, even in cases where known single-gene associations are not apparent. This approach underscores the potential of leveraging gene modules to gain deeper insights into the etiology of complex diseases and their treatment mechanisms, marking a significant advancement in functional genomics and the pursuit of precision medicine.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach that leverages an omnigenic model to offer a gene module perspective in genetic research. This method's versatility permits the incorporation of various data types into a single analysis framework, facilitating a comprehensive exploration of how clusters of functionally related genes impact complex traits. Through this lens, we can discern shared and distinct transcriptomic features across different traits and forecast the influence of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping gene-trait connections and drug-responsive gene expressions onto a unified latent space. This integration process utilizes gene-trait associations derived from TWAS in PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], alongside public RNA-seq data from recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], to construct a low-dimensional representation. This approach reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in pertinent cell types, such as the link between hypothyroidism and T cells. Notably, our findings in the discovery cohort of PhenomeXcan replicated within the eMERGE network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], underscoring the robustness of our module-based analysis. Furthermore, our method outperforms traditional single-gene analyses in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease connections, highlighting the utility of examining tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms through gene modules. This module-centric perspective not only enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations but also identifies promising therapeutic targets that may not be evident when examining individual genes. Consequently, PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm shift in genetic studies, offering a more nuanced understanding of complex diseases and their treatment strategies.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic approach that adopts a gene module perspective for genetic research. Our method's adaptability enables the integration of diverse data types into a unified analysis framework. We demonstrate that this approach allows for the identification of how clusters of functionally interconnected genes impact complex traits, the recognition of shared and unique transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and the prediction of the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional changes onto a shared latent space. This is accomplished by amalgamating vast numbers of gene-trait associations, derived from TWAS using PhenomeXcan, and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000, into a compact space formulated from extensive public RNA-seq data (recount2). Through a matrix factorization technique that identifies gene modules based on sparsity and alignment with existing biological pathways, PhenoPLIER elucidates the relationship between diseases and gene modules expressed in pertinent cell typesfor instance, linking hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Notably, our method's capacity to leverage large, diverse RNA-seq datasets enables the identification of modules associated with specific cell types under distinct conditions or disease states. Our findings in the discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan) were successfully replicated in the eMERGE network phase III, serving as our replication cohort. Additionally, a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells highlighted stronger associations with modules than with individual genes, underscoring our method's superiority in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease connections by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. This module-based approach not only facilitates a more accurate prediction of drug-disease relationships but also uncovers stable trait clusters linked to relevant tissues, thereby offering a novel perspective in genetic research. By focusing on gene groups functioning synergistically within specific cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations, presenting a paradigm shift in understanding complex diseases and their treatment strategies.

Our method is designed with the flexibility to combine various types of data, allowing for a comprehensive analysis that encompasses both genetic traits and the effects of drugs on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by integrating a vast array of gene-trait associations, primarily using transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083], and drug transcriptional profiles from the LINCS L1000 project [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], into a unified, low-dimensional representation. This representation is derived from a comprehensive analysis of public gene expression data, including tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples from recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], utilizing a matrix factorization approach that identifies gene modules based on specific criteria, including sparsity and alignment with existing biological pathways [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]. Our findings reveal significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as the linkage of hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Importantly, these module-trait associations observed in our discovery cohort from PhenomeXcan were replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], underscoring the robustness of our approach. Furthermore, a CRISPR screen analysis of lipid regulation in HepG2 cells highlighted the advantages of a module-based method over traditional single-gene analyses, particularly in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. Our approach not only offers a more reliable means of investigating drug-disease relationships but also uncovers stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, suggesting a new paradigm in the interpretation of genetic studies. By focusing on the collective action of gene groups within specific cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances our ability to detect and interpret genetic associations, thereby offering a promising avenue for identifying novel therapeutic targets and facilitating drug repurposing efforts, even when known gene associations are not evident. This represents a significant shift towards a more mechanistic understanding of complex diseases and their treatment, paving the way for advances in functional genomics and personalized medicine.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel method that leverages an omnigenic approach to enhance the understanding of genetic influences on complex traits through a gene module perspective. This innovative technique allows for the integration of diverse data types, such as gene-trait associations and drug response profiles, into a unified analysis framework. By employing this module-based viewpoint, we demonstrate the ability to discern how clusters of functionally interconnected genes impact various complex traits, identify common and unique transcriptomic features across these traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. Specifically, PhenoPLIER utilizes a sophisticated matrix factorization technique to map both gene-trait associations, derived from tools like TWAS via PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083], and drug-induced gene expression changes, sourced from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], into a shared, low-dimensional space. This space is constructed from a vast repository of public gene expression data, including tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples from recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], and is designed to highlight gene modules that are biologically meaningful and relevant to specific cell types and conditions. Our findings reveal significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in pertinent cell types, such as T cells for hypothyroidism and brain cell types for neuropsychiatric disorders. Furthermore, we validate these associations in an independent cohort from the eMERGE network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] and demonstrate the utility of our approach in a CRISPR screen focused on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. Notably, our module-centric analysis offers superior prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease connections by capturing the nuanced, tissue-specific pathways underlying drug actions, such as the immune mechanism implicated in the efficacy of niacin for cardiovascular conditions. This suggests that considering gene modules, rather than individual genes, provides a more accurate lens through which to examine the intricate relationships between drugs and diseases. Ultimately, PhenoPLIER represents a shift towards a more integrative and robust framework for genetic research, highlighting the potential of gene modules to uncover novel insights into complex disease mechanisms and therapeutic strategies. This approach not only enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations but also opens new avenues for identifying promising therapeutic targets, especially in cases where traditional single-gene analyses fall short.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic approach that leverages gene modules to enhance the analysis of genetic studies. Our method's versatility enables the integration of various data types into a unified analytical framework. We demonstrate that this gene module perspective facilitates the understanding of how clusters of functionally related genes impact complex traits, identifies common and unique transcriptomic features across traits, and predicts the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional changes into a shared latent space. This is accomplished by amalgamating extensive gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) with public gene expression data from a vast collection of RNA-seq samples (recount2), all within a low-dimensional space derived through a matrix factorization technique that identifies gene modules based on sparsity and alignment with existing biological pathways. Our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in pertinent cell typesfor instance, linking hypothyroidism with T cells and various disorders with specific brain cell types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER's ability to leverage models from diverse RNA-seq datasets allows for the identification of modules corresponding to cell types in particular conditions or diseases. Notably, module-trait associations identified in our discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan) were successfully replicated in the eMERGE network phase III, serving as our replication cohort. Additionally, through a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we found that module associations provide stronger trait correlations than those with individual genes, highlighting the method's superior predictive power for FDA-approved drug-disease connections by elucidating tissue-specific pathophysiological pathways. This module-based approach not only offers a more effective way to explore drug-disease interactions but also uncovers stable trait clusters linked to relevant tissues, suggesting a novel paradigm for interpreting genetic studies. By focusing on gene groups rather than single genes, PhenoPLIER enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations, offering new insights into complex diseases and their treatment options, thereby marking a significant shift in the understanding of genetic contributions to complex traits.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative approach that utilizes an omnigenic model to enhance the analysis of genetic studies by focusing on gene modules. This method's versatility allows for the integration of various data types, enabling a comprehensive analysis that combines genetic associations and drug response profiles. By adopting a module-based perspective, PhenoPLIER facilitates the understanding of how clusters of functionally related genes contribute to complex traits, discerns unique and shared transcriptomic features across these traits, and predicts the impact of drug interventions on gene activity. Central to our approach is the mapping of gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional changes into a unified, lower-dimensional space. This is achieved by incorporating gene-trait associations identified through TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], alongside vast public gene expression datasets, into a latent space learned via matrix factorization [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. Our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, highlighting the method's ability to identify cell-specific and stimulus-specific modules. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER's utility is underscored by its replication of module-trait associations in the eMERGE network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] and its success in linking FDA-approved drugs to diseases through tissue-specific pathways, surpassing traditional single-gene analyses in predicting drug-disease connections. Notably, our module-based approach also uncovers stable trait clusters related to relevant tissues, offering new insights into the relationship between complex traits and potential therapeutic targets. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a significant shift in how genetic studies are interpreted, moving beyond individual gene associations to emphasize the role of gene networks in elucidating the etiology of complex diseases and identifying novel therapeutic avenues. This strategy not only enhances the robustness of genetic association detection and interpretation but also highlights the potential for uncovering alternative, more promising therapeutic targets, thereby advancing our understanding of complex diseases and their treatment mechanisms.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach that leverages the concept of gene modulesgroups of functionally related genesto enhance genetic studies. Our method is distinctive in its ability to integrate various types of data, allowing for a comprehensive analysis that sheds light on how these gene groups influence complex traits, uncover similarities and differences in their transcriptomic profiles across different traits, and predict the impact of drug interventions on gene activity. Importantly, PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping both gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional changes onto a unified, low-dimensional space. This space is constructed by integrating a wide array of gene-trait associations, notably those from TWAS in PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083], and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], using public gene expression data from an extensive RNA-seq dataset (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). Our method employs a matrix factorization approach with specific constraints to extract relevant gene modules, aligning with known biological pathways [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]. This analysis reveals that certain diseases are closely associated with gene modules active in pertinent cell types, exemplified by connections between hypothyroidism and T cells, and neuropsychiatric disorders with brain cell types. Furthermore, our findings are validated in a replication cohort from the eMERGE network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], and a CRISPR screen further supports the robustness of module-trait associations over single-gene links, particularly in lipid metabolism. Notably, our module-based analysis more accurately predicts FDA-approved drug-disease relationships by capturing the tissue-specific mechanisms underlying these interactions. This suggests that considering gene modules, rather than individual genes, offers a more effective framework for exploring drug-disease connections and identifying potential therapeutic targets. Ultimately, PhenoPLIER proposes a shift from the traditional single-gene focus to a broader perspective that considers the collective action of gene groups, enhancing our ability to uncover and understand the genetic underpinnings of complex diseases and their treatment options. This shift not only improves the robustness of genetic association studies but also opens new avenues for discovering promising therapeutic targets, even in cases where known single-gene associations fail to provide insights.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic method that adopts a gene module perspective for genetic research. Our approach is versatile, allowing the integration of various data types into a unified analysis framework. We demonstrate that this module-centric view enables the prediction of how functionally related gene groups impact complex traits, identifies both common and unique transcriptomic features across traits, and predicts the effects of drug interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER consolidates gene-trait connections and drug-induced transcriptional changes into a shared latent space by amalgamating thousands of gene-trait associations (sourced from TWAS via PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) with a vast array of public gene expression data from numerous RNA-seq samples (recount2). Utilizing a latent space defined through matrix factorization, which identifies gene modules based on sparsity and alignment with existing pathways, we uncover significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in pertinent cell typesfor instance, linking hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Our method's ability to leverage extensive, diverse RNA-seq datasets enables the identification of modules related to specific cell types in particular conditions or diseases. Notably, we find that module-trait associations identified in our discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan) are replicated in the eMERGE network phase III (our replication cohort). Additionally, through CRISPR screening for lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we establish stronger associations with modules than with single genes, highlighting the superiority of our module-based approach in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease connections by elucidating tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. This suggests that gene modules offer a more effective means for exploring drug-disease interactions than individual genes. Further analysis of the phenotype-module landscape uncovers stable trait clusters linked to relevant tissues, suggesting a nuanced interplay between lipids and various disorders, including cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric conditions. Overall, PhenoPLIER shifts the focus from isolated genes to groups of synergistically acting genes, enhancing the detection and interpretation of genetic associations. This study not only demonstrates the method's ability to identify novel and promising candidate targets where single gene associations may fail but also signifies a paradigm shift in genetic study interpretation, paving the way for deeper insights into complex disease mechanisms and therapeutic strategies.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel strategy that adopts an omnigenic framework to enhance the analysis of genetic studies through a gene module lens. This method is designed with the versatility to amalgamate diverse types of data, facilitating a comprehensive analysis. Our findings demonstrate that by focusing on clusters of functionally interconnected genes, PhenoPLIER can elucidate the genetic underpinnings of complex traits, uncover both shared and unique transcriptomic features across different traits, and predict the impact of drug interventions on gene activity. Specifically, PhenoPLIER consolidates gene-trait linkages and drug response data into a unified, low-dimensional space by integrating voluminous gene-trait associationsleveraging Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]and drug transcriptional profiles from the LINCS L1000 project [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], against a backdrop of extensive public gene expression data (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). Through a sophisticated matrix factorization method [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003], PhenoPLIER identifies gene modules that not only exhibit specific patterns of expression but also resonate with established biological pathways. Our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in pertinent cell types, such as T cells in hypothyroidism and brain cell types in neuropsychiatric disorders. Moreover, the application of PhenoPLIER to diverse and large RNA-seq datasets enables the detection of cell-specific modules under various conditions, including disease states. Notably, the associations identified in our primary dataset (PhenomeXcan) were corroborated in the eMERGE network phase III as a replication cohort [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], and a CRISPR screen further validated the relevance of these modules in lipid regulation. Compared to traditional single-gene analyses, PhenoPLIER's module-centric approach more effectively predicts links between FDA-approved drugs and diseases by capturing the nuanced, tissue-specific mechanisms underlying drug actions. This enhanced ability to predict drug-disease relationships underscores the potential of gene modules to provide deeper insights than individual genes. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER facilitates the identification of stable trait clusters associated with specific tissues, illustrating complex interactions among cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In sum, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm from analyzing isolated genes to considering cohesive groups of genes, offering a more robust framework for understanding genetic associations and uncovering novel therapeutic targets. This approach marks a significant advancement in interpreting genetic studies, paving the way for novel insights into complex disease etiology and the mechanisms of drug action.

This method stands out for its ability to seamlessly integrate diverse types of data, facilitating a comprehensive analysis that reveals how clusters of functionally connected genes impact complex traits, uncovers common and unique transcriptomic characteristics across different traits, and predicts the effects of drug treatments on gene activity. By synthesizing gene-trait associations from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug response profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a unified, low-dimensional space derived from extensive public gene expression datasets like recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], PhenoPLIER offers a powerful tool for mapping these associations. Our findings demonstrate that diseases correlate significantly with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, offering insights into the cellular basis of various conditions, from hypothyroidism to neuropsychiatric disorders. This module-centric approach not only enhances the prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease connections by capturing tissue-specific disease mechanisms but also reveals intricate trait clusters linked to relevant tissues, suggesting a more nuanced understanding of drug-disease relationships compared to traditional single-gene analyses. Ultimately, PhenoPLIER represents a shift towards considering the collective action of gene groups in disease mechanisms, offering a more robust framework for identifying genetic associations and uncovering new therapeutic targets, even when individual gene associations remain elusive. This paradigm shift underscores the potential of our approach to deepen our understanding of complex diseases and inform the development of targeted treatments.

Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

import re

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

# capture current references in the output using a regex
output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)

n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not in references])
return (n_fake_refs == 0)
